section.name: Reading and Writing Styx files
section.p: The most common tasks (from the client's point of view at least) in a Styx system are reading from and writing to files. There are several ways to do this, each with advantages and disadvantages. In this section of the tutorial, we'll go through the options.

subsection.name: Setting up
subsection.p:
In all of the examples in this section, we'll use the SimpleServer from earlier in this tutorial. This simply serves up a single file that holds its contents in memory. Run this server by running:
JStyxRun uk.ac.rdg.resc.jstyx.tutorial.SimpleServer
from the bin/ directory of your JStyx distribution.

All the client programs we shall write are based on the SimpleClient from earlier in this tutorial. In each of the examples below we shall first write some data to the file on the server, then we shall read it back. All the functions described below are part of the CStyxFile class.
All the code below can be found in the ReadingAndWriting class, including full comments.

subsection.name: getContents() and setContents()
subsection.p: The easiest way to read from and write to files is to use the getContents() and setContents() methods, as used in the original SimpleClient. These methods are suitable if the entire contents of the file can fit sensibly in a String, i.e. for relatively small data volumes.
